predicted: Test-tube babies and infants who can be bought via vending machine would be around in 1980.
happened: In-vitro fertilization. The world’s first test-tube baby was born in 1978.
caption: Maureen O’Sullivan and John Garrick are among the stars of “Just Imagine.”

predicted: Obsession with computers can interfere with relationships: “You’re not in love with me. You’re in love with (the machine),” Katharine Hepburn’s Bunny Watson tells Spencer Tracy’s Richard Sumner in the final scene.
happened: Too much gadgetry indeed interferes with relationships.
caption: “Desk Set” is among the many films starring Katharine Hepburn and Spencer Tracy.

predicted: Earthlings don’t have physical intercourse anymore. Instead, they use exaltation-transference pills, known as sex pills, as Barbarella (Jane Fonda) explains.
happened: The Food and Drug Administration approved Viagra in 1998 — the first such drug to treat erectile dysfunction. Others soon followed.
caption: Jane Fonda was the title character in “Barbarella,” which also starred John Phillip Law.

predicted: In this Woody Allen screenplay, it’s 2173, and people can get into a cylindrical device called the Orgasmatron to quickly achieve orgasm.
caption: Woody Allen was ahead of his time in “Sleeper.” The Orgasmatron is still ahead of its time.

predicted: Replicants, which are human-like robots, can form relationships, sometimes deadly ones, with real humans.
happened: Amazon’s virtual assistant Alexa and other voice helpers, like Apple’s Siri, are less-lethal lifelines for some humans.
caption: Harrison Ford is Rick Deckard, joined by Sean Young as Rachael, in “Blade Runner.”

predicted: Sentient machines: A San Francisco man pours Champagne on his computer and it develops emotions and falls in love (albeit unsuccessfully).
happened: Alexa has received hundreds of thousands of marriage proposals. Among her responses: “Sorry, I'm not the marrying type.”
caption: Virginia Madsen, with Maxwell Caulfield (center) and Lenny Von Dohlen in “Electric Dreams.”

predicted: Simulated sexual intercourse without touching, using helmet-like devices. Sandra Bullock’s character is into it; Sylvester Stallone’s, not so much.
happened: The pornography industry has enthusiastically taken up virtual reality. Haptic feedback — providing a sense of touch in a virtual experience — is also coming.
caption: Sandra Bullock had a different sort of sex scene in “Demolition Man.”

predicted: Robots can develop sentience. A robot butler (Robin Williams) undergoes operations to become more human and falls in love.
happened: Computers simulating emotions, let alone genuinely experiencing them, remains an academic theory. We sure do love our phones, though.
caption: Robin Williams (left), Oliver Platt and Kiersten Warren add humanity in “Bicentennial Man.”
